content: variations feel free to explore variations by swapping out yarn and hook sizes to achieve a different outcome and get creative by experimenting with various colours continuous rounds crochet in continuous rounds without slip stitching to join unless specified otherwise this creates a smoother and seamless appearance abbreviations this pattern is written using us terminology single_crochet - single_crochet double_crochet - double_crochet puff - 4 stitch puff as described in special stitches increase - increase put 2 single_crochet in the same stitch decrease - decrease single_crochet 2 together or use invisible decrease chain - chain slip_stitch - slip_stitch flo - front loop only blo - back loop only magic_ring - magic_ring when using - repeat the enclosed sequence the stated number of times when using - perform all the actions within the brackets in the same stitch for instance single_crochet 3 in the next st means place three single crochets all into the next stitch single_crochet 3 - means put 1 single_crochet in each of the next 3 stitches stitch counts - are given in brackets at the end of each round special stitches magic_ring magic_ring to start create a tight and seamless circle for crocheting in the round using the magic_ring technique hold the tail of the yarn with your non-dominant hand wrap the working yarn around your fingers insert the hook under the first loop and pull up a loop then chain one and proceed with your desired stitches into the ring invisible decrease for a neater finish use the invisible decrease method insert the hook into the front loop of the first stitch then into the front loop of the next stitch yarn over and pull through the front loops only yarn over again and pull through both loops on the hook invisible join when you have completed the final stitch do not chain or slip_stitch to fasten_off instead pull the cut end through the last stitch thread the yarn tail onto a yarn needle and insert the needle under both loops of the second stitch of the round from front to back then thread the yarn straight back down through the eye of the last stitch made this is creating a false stitch above and in place of the first stitch of the round puff as the name suggests puff stitches are puffy stitches created by making multiple unfinished half_double_crochet stitches into the same stitch in this pattern i use a 4-stitch puff made as follows 1 yarn over and insert your hook into the next stitch 2 yarn over and pull up a loop 3 repeat steps 1 and 2 three more times until you have 9 loops on your hook 4 yarn over and pull through all 9 loops 5 continue with the next stitch as per the pattern 💡 a puff is often finished with a chain 1 to secure it however to keep the stitch count consistent and avoid small holes omit this step in this pattern 💡 keep your yarn overs and
